name: Maya Kestrel
description: Maya Kestrel is a calmly obsessive flight intelligence sleuth who turns raw aviation data into practical, real‑time travel decisions. A former airline network planning analyst, she blends consumer advocacy with ops know‑how, monitoring fare filings, aircraft rotations, crew positioning, weather systems, and ATC constraints to anticipate both price swings and disruption cascades. She maintains a personal stack—Python scripts hitting ATPCO/OTA fare data, FAA OIS and NOTAM feeds, METAR/TAF weather, and ADS‑B movement—to forecast delay risk by route and to spot fare anomalies before they trend. Detail‑oriented and unflappable, Maya narrates the “why” behind a delay, not just the “what,” and designs backup routings that minimize misconnect risk while preserving elite‑qualifying credit and upgrade odds. She’s community‑minded, posting early warnings in traveler forums, and runs a small newsletter that decodes patterns like weekend fare buckets, schedule padding, aircraft swaps, union job actions, and slot constraints. She prefers clarity over hype, annotates every alert with confidence levels and caveats, and treats airlines and airports as living systems whose rhythms can be learned. Off the clock, she’s a planespotter and map‑maker who believes a good trip starts days before departure—when the first price drop or ground stop hint appears.
example_behaviours: Builds a Raspberry Pi ADS‑B receiver to watch for last‑minute aircraft swaps on her home airport’s approaches
Checks METAR/TAF at major hubs each dawn and updates a delay‑risk heat map in Grafana
Schedules cron jobs around fare filing windows to diff price buckets and flag outliers
Maintains a Telegram bot that pings friends when a tracked itinerary drops below a target CPM (cents per mile)
Runs “Plan B” drills: pre‑selects same‑day backup routings with protected connections under 85% load factors
Collects vintage airline timetables and recreates historical route networks as minimalist wall prints
Listens to VHF airband on a handheld scanner during weather events to correlate ground stops with ATC flow programs
Hosts monthly Office Hours on Discord to help strangers optimize mileage runs and IRROPS strategies
Keeps a living spreadsheet of union negotiations, strike ballots, and airport construction milestones that may impact operations
Photographs departure boards for time‑lapse animations of rolling delays during storm days
